reviews.text: Some of the greatest horror in this eminently suspenseful film comes not from the sci-fi fiction of monsters but from the very visceral imagery of how what we take for granted could be gone in an instant ... either vanished for good or irrevocably changed
If you love horror movies, if you love this universe, if you love Joseph Quinn from Stranger Things, or if you just love cats, A Quiet Place: Day One delivers.

Sarnoski makes the scenes of human intimacy as substantial as anything I’ve yet seen in this series. But just as I did with the first two, I staggered out of the theater glad the movie hadn’t run longer, and suffering from another concussion headache.
Good scares, characters I cared about, and a cute cat. But what does this add to the Quiet Place mythos? Nothing, really.
A Quiet Place: Day One brings all the scares and extended tension from the original back in play with some creatively staged action sequences and engaging performances from its two leads.
Nyong’o and Quinn provide emotionally breathtaking performances, and their portrayal of grief, anxiety, terror and perseverance is extraordinary.

With effective jump scares and flawless production design from Simon Bowles (Apartment 7A), that ensures Manhattan looks suitably war torn, A Quiet Place: Day One delivers the goods without feeling wildly inventive.

Gives us two protagonists absolutely worth our empathy and investment (three if you include Frodo, the most chill cat in a stressful situation since Jones watched Harry Dean Stanton get eviscerated aboard the Nostromo).

While I do think that certain stories should end, I will admit that "A Quiet Place" still has enough excitement, enough possibilities, that this third outing may just be a precursor to at least one more ...
With a fresh vision, a new cast and a scare rate that just won’t quit, this bucks the trend for horrors with diminishing returns.
The special effects are convincing, but Sarnoski is smart enough to know that less is more.

Sarnoski does an excellent job with the script and direction and is greatly aided by the fantastic actors. It’s a strong story with an interesting angle that finds more to explore in this world of “A Quiet Place.”
The movie functions less as a genre justification of us vs. them, and more as a lyrical indie tribute to found family and the value of friendship, love, and life in the face of inevitable mortality.

I must urge the Academy Awards to make a new category: Best Performance by an Animal. This is a category that has been sadly ignored. There are a lot of working animals who deserve recognition for helping assist a star build their character.

Day One delivers a wildly effective big city disaster film while making the most of the franchise’s core concept and keeping the series character-first. Lupita Nyong'o's energy and fight are hugely captivating. An ace digging into character complexities.
While the human actors are well drawn enough to build interest and make us care about them, it’s the alien antagonists that command the screen and garner our attention.
Even with Nyong’o and Quinn, and even with the movie’s emphasis on how people deal with impending death, Day One comes across as a familiar, slight, routine horror flick.
A Quiet Place: Day One is a very pleasant surprise. I’m not sure there’s much more fuel in the franchise’s tank after this, but three good films should be good enough for anyone.

A unique marriage of the disease melodrama and alien invasion sub-genre, [this} would have been better served as an unrelated indie feature than a tacked-on franchise entry. Regardless, Lupita Nyong'o's superb performance undoubtedly enhances...
Three movies in, and it’s quite impressive how the Quiet Place series has managed to deliver consistent quality from its seemingly singular hook.
There’s no reason to stay invested in something so uninventive. A Quiet Place: Day One is nothing but a dull apocalyptic routine that doesn’t pay off.

The film is another example that well-rounded characters, with earthly problems and goals and with whom it is easy to empathize, are much more important than any contemporary summer blockbuster's special effects.
While anchored by strong performances from Lupita Nyong’o and Joseph Quinn, Day One brought nothing new to the franchise and relied too heavily on jump scares.

First: how many of these damn things are there? Whenever anyone cuts a loud fart (it doesn't happen onscreen, but you know thousands gave their lives for flatulence) there's an alien waiting to smear their blood on a wall.

Surpasses expectations for a B/B-minus franchise, going hyper-focused and resisting the urge to go bigger and broader and explain, explain, explain all the whys and wherefores of what's happening. It's the best of the three films, by far.

Lupita Nyong’o’s face is the most effective visual effect in A Quiet Place: Day One. We commit to the story and the world because her eyes tell us so, but beyond her penetrating stare little else in the film feels persuasive enough to commit to.
The entertainment value centers around Nyong'o's performance, which is very good.
It's an emotional, smart thriller/horror/sci-fi tale that sets the stage for the first two films.

The franchise – unlike many that are stretched to the limit – still has value. Putting someone of Nyong’o's caliber in the lead polishes the concept and provides the kind of sheen we haven’t seen since M. Night Shyamalan started directing.
Michael Sarnoski writes and directs the best film in the franchise so far, something that shouldn't come as a surprise to anyone who was floored by his debut feature, "Pig". [Full Review in Spanish]

A Quiet Place Day One centers itself around the human needed for companionship, strength, and a reason to go on. Samira is tired of the pain and she’s looking for one more trip to Harlem to say goodbye and let the teeth fall where they may.
An intriguing prequel that complicates the series' nuts-and-bolts horror-thriller premise with a disquieting rumination on mortality and meaning. Plus: a very good cat.

There is a real emotional core to this film and a real emotional journey that Lupita Nyong'o goes through as she tries to keep herself, and her cat, alive. This film is absolutely fantastic. It's thrilling, it's terrifying., and keeps you guessing.
Director Michael Sarnoski continues the franchise's winning streak, delivering what might be the best entry yet.
A serviceable prequel -- and that's the nicest thing I can say about it... I was invested enough, and it was OK.
While the plot races forward, the characters lag, offering as much depth as a slice of New York-style pizza—tasty but ultimately thin.
A Quiet Place: Day One, Nyong’o agrees to her own stigmatization -- a perpetual victim archetype in another shabby enterprise.
There isn’t wall-to-wall violence. There’s wall-to-wall expectations of it, and that’s even more chilling.
In the film’s sci-fi world, noise is death and quiet is life. Could there be a better metaphor for the dynamics of our digital age?
Despite Lupita Nyong'o's magnificent performance, this installment ends up lacking the tension of its two unsettling predecessors. [Full Review in Spanish]
Not as "quiet' as the previous versions, this has a little more dialogue and enormously nuanced performances from Oscar winner Lupita Nyong'o and Joseph Quinn

A blown-to-bits bus sequence, with shadows of ashen-faced 9/11 footage, kicks off her Odyssean quest not to get off the island, but instead to have one last slice of pizza ... This quiet determination ... lends the film a beautiful melancholy.

Centring the film on a woman, specifically a Black woman’s experiences and her journey, elevates A Quiet Place: Day One from the merely imitative or reductive into something more, something arguably better.

This prequel is an assured work, one that brings the action and scares while at the same time treading fertile new thematic ground. It’s invigorating to see a franchise film be this concerned about being a great movie first and brand extension second.

"Watching the death angels infest New York City architecture like a nest of creepy-crawly spiders is perfect. What’s the point of long leggy monsters if they don’t have buildings, crazy skylines and subway tunnels to crawl all over?!"
...a watchable yet somewhat disappointing endeavor that ultimately fares best in its promising, engaging opening half hour...

A surprisingly human story about a pair of isolated individuals who just so happen to find themselves in A Quiet Place film. Lupita Nyong'o and Joseph Quinn are fantastic and the film does right by its feline co-star (the true third lead of the film!)

A Quiet Place: Day One may not bring anything new to the genre or to its own cinematic universe when it comes to expand its borders, but it sure delivers top notch Human Drama as Nyong'o's performance elevates it all.

Though... Day One is equipped with a few plot defects, Michael Sarnoski’s sci-fi horror film more than makes up for it with intense action scenes, deeply moving performances, and a poignant message that emphasizes the significance of human connection.
Like the piano music, the film reminds us that even in the darkest and most desolate moments, art remains a beacon of hope. [Full review in Spanish]

Besides delving into the human condition and how disposable we are, A Quiet Place: Day One does not forget that it is a horror film, and while it falters a little on that end, it never falls. [Full review in Spanish]

While “Day One” follows a somewhat similar blueprint as its predecessors, the human element really has an impact. Nyong’o is the essential piece, adding a very different dynamic to the horror movie protagonist.
Michael Sarnoski has perfected the trick of turning genre film into poetic cinema.

A Quiet Place: Day One” presented the opportunity to answer questions the first two movies didn’t exactly need to but it didn't. Maybe the filmmakers needed to give us a reason to watch “A Quiet Place Part III,” which seems likely the next step.
Nyong’o has already proven with “Us” that she is a beyond compelling silent star. “A Quiet Place: Day One” is worth a trip to the box office for.
... Fine, professional, but definitively not a transcendent entry into mainstream Hollywood. [Full review in Spanish]
Director Michael Sarnoski has done a huge disservice to the original product.
While Day One packs a poignant punch, it's not exactly in contention for scariest movie of the year.

A Quiet Place: Day One is a visually stunning and suspenseful thrill ride, but narrative inconsistencies and a shift in tone hold it back from reaching the heights of its predecessors. Still, fans of the franchise will find much to enjoy.
As a franchise prequel, A Quiet Place: Day One doesn’t do enough world-building, but Lupita Nyong’o makes it worth a watch.
As in with the excellent Cage-led "Pig", competent director Sarnoski once again seeks affirmation and traits of genuine and deep humanity amid hostile environments. [Full review in Spanish]
Features similar traits that plagued and uplifted its two predecessors.
In the third entry of the “Quiet Place” franchise, death not only falls from the sky, it’s already in the eyes of cancer patients at a hospice just outside New York City.
A Quiet Place: Day One is very similar to the so-called blockbusters of the '80s... [Full review in Spanish]

The first two (especially the first one) had a dark, mysterious, and dangerous edge, but this one seemed slow, predictable and not very scary. It’s pretty grim and doesn’t offer a happy resolutions so it’s a strange summer film.

Michael Sarnoski makes the jump from indies to blockbusters with Day One, but brings his character-focused sensibilities to the apocalyptic spectacle that’s been promised. It’s the best of the franchise by far.

I wouldn’t say the movie is a classic of its kind. But Sarnoski, with help from his creative sound design and effects teams, fills a fleet 99 minutes with the high-anxiety stress movies such as this are meant to deliver.
By the time Day One reaches its beautifully rendered and deeply moving conclusion, we're all in.
It could have been a cheap cash-in that killed the mystery of the creepy sound-seeking monsters, but this prequel is instead a surprisingly riveting, intricately designed, even touching adventure.
A Quiet Place: Day One is worth watching. This silence-driven thriller adds layers of realism and immediacy to its suspense as it draws the audience deeper into the characters’ struggles.

While it’s got that spine-tingling dread John Krasinski forged with the first two installments, Sarnoski refocuses the story into studying the basic decencies we’re capable of for our neighbors on the fly in the face of grave danger.
If you’re looking for a film this summer that will deliver thrills, laughs, and heart, then A Quiet Place: Day One might be the movie for you.

A wonderful prequel that continues to give prestige to the series. Nyong’o delivers one of the best performances in a franchise studio release this year in a story that will make the viewer appreciate daily life’s slow, quiet moments.
While not quite a match for its predecessors, this wilful winding back of the clock to explain the origins of all that make-a-noise-and-die mayhem is not without its own merits.
There's a lot of melancholy and emotion to go with the jump scares and suspense.

I haven’t felt this engaged with a depiction of the apocalypse in years. In such uncertain times, the greatest compliment I can give Day One is that it allowed me to process my own anxieties about the world through the power of cinema.
I think this was the most emotional one for me.

Credulity stretching logic gaps notwithstanding, though, [Sarnoski] keeps a healthy focus on character over spectacle and, in the early set-pieces, approaches it as a proper silent film, with Lyong’o’s wonderfully expressive face speaking volumes.
Their unlikely, but touching, bond is the reason this series remains compelling, but also handing this project off to Sarnoski was a bold and wise move.

Unlike the previous Quiet Place movies, I was never scared...  It's a good, solid piece of work but it's not on a par with the previous two installments, even though it has at its center a very good performance.
Other invasion films bank on the glory of fighting back for life, liberty and the pursuit of happiness. “A Quiet Place: Day One” is all about the human spirit.
A worthy companion piece to the first two Quiet Place films.
Much larger in scale thanks to its setting, the film is a roller coaster ride of tension, with an immersive soundscape and engrossing apocalyptic imagery.
For the human players, this is a showcase of strong, silent performance.

A Quiet Place: Day One prioritizes strong performances and monster mayhem. Lupita Nyong’o and Joseph Quinn deliver exceptional performances. But the storyline is borderline idiotic and the Eric character dribbles stupidity in every direction.
Writer-director Michael Sarnoski brings his internalised approach to storytelling, adding an involving twist to this prequel to John Krasinski's hushed 2018 dramatic horror.

Some might argue that a prequel wasn’t necessary. We already saw the initial invasion in A Quiet Place II, but what Day One does compellingly is how it reveals the reality of when a city as bustling and boisterous as New York is forced into silence.
Director/screenwriter Michael Sarnoski, handily proves that he's capable of delivering something on this scale. He treats the concept respectfully.
a phenomenal film that subverts expectations in rich and affecting ways. ... a personal, poignant adventure about cherishing what matters most.
Sticks true to its themes about self-sacrifice, courage, and finding hope in even the direst circumstances.
With most of the apocalyptic mayhem happening off-screen, it is Lupita Nyong’o who manages to grab the eye and keep it in ‘A Quiet Place: Day One’
Avoiding being thoughtless, “Day One” is good popcorn fun, designed to raise the heart rate for its thankfully brisk 99 minutes.
A beautiful horror story marked by tension, chaos, and unexpected doses of humanity. [Full review in Spanish]
The excitement may wane a little. However, A Quiet Place: Day One has a number of strong, resonant images to offer. [Full review in Spanish]
The unnecessary prequel to A Quiet Place is saved from disaster by the great chemistry and performances of its leading couple: Lupita Nyong'o and Joseph Quinn. [Full review in Spanish]
The film moves forward in a straight line, vehement and effective. [Full review in Spanish]
This is a stylish and satisfying prequel that elegantly integrates Sam’s poet’s sensibility into the storytelling.
Had this prequel focused on rude people learning to shut up because otherwise radar-headed bat-Pterodactyls would eat their heads, we would've had something.
A Quiet Place: Day One cuts through the noise to deliver an intimate and engaging story about survival.

Great human story element of survival with two great performances that really made for an emotionally satisfying experience. Unfortunately it didn’t have the same high tension filled, thrilling or scary elements as the previous films.
Day One builds with purpose and fervor, but ultimately drifts into the predictable.

Although some scenes are suffused with suffocating tension and there are plenty of flashy special effects sequences, Day One at times feels more like an art house movie than something made for mainstream audiences.

The silent set pieces have the potential to get the best out of filmmakers or quickly slide into parody, but they've found a surprisingly emotional experience worth telling in fighting for the will to live vs. sliding into acceptance of one’s fate.
Indeed, the action set pieces are fine but also perfunctory... “Day One” is on much surer ground when dealing with the quiet that bookends the storms.
To watch “A Quiet Place: Day One” is to recalibrate your senses — not to the alien horror movie you know is in store but rather, to the intimate human drama it hangs onto.
Day One is a prequel that doesn't need to exist, but makes a good case for its existence anyway.

Despite a lot of strong action pieces being spoiled in the trailers and not adding much to the overall lore of "A Quiet Place", this film was a very tense, surprisingly intimate story that provided an inspired performance by Lupita Nyong'o.
Has nothing fresh to say.

The notable performances by Lupita Nyong’o, Joseph Quinn, and Alex Wolff significantly elevate the movie, with Nyong’o, in particular, delivering a powerful, intense performance that underscores the importance of finding hope and joy amid despair.

... turns out to be a welcome oasis of strong character and believable motivation, not qualities we expect in a summer blockbuster…getting audiences back into cinema is proving to be like herding cats; Mike Sarnoski does both here with real success.’
A single act of kindness. A momentary instance of compassion. That’s all it takes to help someone in their darkest hour. Heck, it may even be enough to save the world.
A Quiet Place: Day One is a masterclass in horror filmmaking. It easily avoids the typical pitfalls of prequels, delivering a story that stands on its own.

Conceptually, this is genius. Put the monsters whose source of terror is noise in one of the noisiest places imaginable... I wish the people were dumber... because the process of them figuring out how to survive would have been immensely interesting.
An adrenaline-filled thrill ride, and it's a perfect addition to the franchise. I was holding my breath throughout the entire film.

Similarly to the previous films, you could literally hear a pin drop, and midway through the film, I found myself not wanting to hear a sound or even shift in my seat. In that regard, this movie works insanely well.
A Quiet Place Day One is the ideal horror film for those who don’t like horror films… but also for those who love them.

Day One is another solid entry in the franchise, that satisfies thanks to great tense action monster moments elevated by wonderful performances by Lupita Nyong'o and Joseph Quinn. That said, not as great as the two previous films. [Full review in Spanish]
A prequel that delivers the franchise’s signature intensity while offering a surprisingly emotional story.
It’s not a bad film, but it’s a disappointingly standard entry in a series that defined itself by subverting and exceeding expectations.

The fact that it is a prequel that does not involve any of the main characters from the previous films is a brilliant decision, since we know little or nothing about what will happen to the two main characters. Full review in Spanish.
“A Quiet Place: Day One” is fine, but the story and special effects are beneath the cast’s capabilities.

A Quiet Place: Day One is a terrible film. Certainly, it's much better than most prequels, not least because it doesn't take away from the original films. But it does fall massively short of both the standards set by the series and of its own ambitions.
It's refreshing to see an apocalyptic movie where the focus is not on cruelty, but rather on people looking after each other.
Powered by an awards-worthy turn from Lupita Nyong'o, horror sequel 'A Quiet Place: Day One' makes some impressive noise.
Nyong’o and Quinn's performances are powerful and heartfelt. Sarnoski does a fantastic job of raising the tension to an unnerving level and keeping it there throughout the film.

The unbelievability of A Quiet Place’s central conceit hasn’t held the series back the way it could due to focus on characters as much as suspense. Day One takes that even further, pushing its threats to the edge of the screen to better center its humans.
Lovers of cinema will also find solace in seeing a good, old-fashioned creature feature thriller, albeit one with some deeper thoughts buried in the dreck.
This origin chapter plays to its own beat while still connecting to the broader world established by John Krasinski. In other words, this is precisely how a prequel should be done.

This thrilling franchise delivers another immersive big screen experience that rattles your senses and resonates in your heart.
[Full Review in Spanish]

The key to these films has always been a need to be quiet as even inconsequential noise attracts the hungry creatures... However, this movie features a surprising amount of talking, which... doesn’t feel like it’s keeping with the spirit of the franchise.
Less a terrifying thrill ride and more of an introspective examination of emotional extremes.
A Quiet Place: Day One is a great theater multi-genre tentpole experience with two great lead performances that remind us of Lupita’s star power.
It’s not a bad movie, certainly one worth watching, but it’s also not as inventive as it could and should have been, considering the abundant skills of the people involved.
Its artful dramatic approach may not sit well with some viewers looking for a more traditionally harrowing and exciting monster movie.

... follows the template of its predecessors by telling a similar story of resilience and survival with a different set of characters in a different setting. By the next day, it doesn’t have much new to say.
I thought “Day One” might be good; I didn’t expect it to be moving.
It’s kind of a miracle that A Quiet Place: Day One is as good as it is.
Fun is fun, but without proper character development, Day One is more fast food than a hardy meal.
I can’t help but feel they are just retreading the same path, almost as if no one thought beyond the initial success of the first film.
A Quiet Place: Day One fails at expanding the possibilities of the concept beyond presenting it in its most maudlin form.
The new installment expands its scope but feels more intimate.
Overall, the performances were freaking phenomenal.

It's a prequel that doesn't break new ground, in fact feels familiar to what you've already experienced before in this franchise. But if you're looking for something to scratch that itch, you'll probably still have yourself a good time.

For a world that often feels unbearable, escapism is no small thing. Instead, it dangles the prospect of summer spectacle only to deliver a nebulous meditation on death without any actual weight to it. When it comes to this series, I’ve heard enough.

Helmed by exceptional lead performances from Nyong’o and Quinn, brilliant technical aspects including beautiful cinematography and clever sound design and most importantly, a perfect balance of character drama and creature feature.

A very well made film, with excellent performances from Nyong'o and Quinn.  However, it's also a surprisingly sad film, and not the popcorn blockbuster one would expect during the summer movie season.  A unique but small in scope dystopian horror film.
Michael Sarnoski (who helmed the great Nicolas Cage indie “Pig”), manages to inject some freshness into a series that is losing some of its novelty.
A Quiet Place: Day One understands that humanity and raw, genuine emotion must be displayed as much as the monsters
The movie is a bouquet of two characters escaping... if you take out the cat, there's nothing left. [Full review in Spanish]
This film should be called A Quiet Kitty: The Search for Fentanyl and Pizza.
Nyong’o holds everything steady, giving us an action heroine guided solely by the desire to experience a moment of normal life before it all comes crashing down.
Animal owners will snicker when Sam has to figure out how to silently open the pull-tab on a can of pet food, an unmistakable crack-rrrrip that makes all hungry creatures come running.
This chapter in the saga is interesting because of the uncertainty. Its goal isn’t to solve problems, but to help remind us to value life.

A Quiet Place: Day One has a brusque, satisfying last shot that’s maybe the year’s best so far. It would be criminal to spoil it, so let’s just say it includes enough layers of irony to make you wonder why you are left smiling.

Scary, suspenseful and driven by two well-developed characters we genuinely care about despite the fact that, by the very nature of the film, they barely speak to one another, A Quiet Place: Day One is another assured and mature entry...
It’s the quieter, emotionally fraught scenes with Lupita Nyong’o and Joseph Quinn that make A Quiet Place: Day One so compelling. That, and one amazing, superheroic cat.

Lupita Nyong'o is playing more notes than we'd expect from the Quiet Place franchise. And the novelty of the franchise hasn't completely worn off. I still found myself listening to my own breath, trying not to trigger the monsters.
It’s the rare prequel that defends its existence with earned emotion, offering us something to explore in between its moments of dread and suspense.

[W]hat could have been a cash grab clearly has loftier aspirations, resulting in a film that’s never boring and just provocative enough to spark big questions about what truly matters in this world when it’s falling apart.
While never invoking the pandemic (the series’ timeline would not allow it anyway), the film manages to be one of the most heartfelt and nuanced explorations on living through it.
Epic, intense and heartbreaking, A Quiet Place: Day One is a visceral gut-punch of a movie that is definitely one to see on the big screen.
It is the excellent Nyong’o, establishing herself with depth and poise in a fine prologue, where the real substance lies.
A Quiet Place Day One has a lean story, but it’s a taught thriller that quietly sneaks up on with an emotional ending that packs a punch.
Think of this one then as an odd Quiet Place backwater, something to keep us invested in the franchise until the next chapter arrives.

'A Quiet Place - Day One'  cleverly narrates the beginning of the tragedy that, until now, has been the mysterious main premise of the saga. But, it avoids adding information to make its script less solid. [Full Review in Spanish]

Once again the QP franchise chooses a more character driven approach with the monsters in the background. We get strong, emotionally charged performances by Nyong'o and Quinn. I think there's more to tell, especially from the military resistance effort.

...Sarnoski and his wonderful lead actress take us through the experience of living our last during a global catastrophe and finding comfort in those final moments in the companionship of a cat and the care of a stranger.
A Quiet Place: Day One is the best directed film in the frightening franchise.
It is really because we care so much about the imperiled duo that A QUIET PLACE: DAY ONE emerges as a worthy addition to this franchise.
Fans will get the rampant space aliens they crave, along with lots of other stuff. In fact, the movie is mostly other stuff, talky and sorrowful. And there's a cat too — quite a lot of cat, actually.
Director Michael Sarnoski weaves a compelling human story highlighting the bond between Eric and Samira amid such a frightening ordeal.

When all is said and done, A QUIET PLACE: DAY ONE 
just isn’t the nightmarish experience it should have been.
While the film does contain its share of jarring noises and sudden appearances by the creatures, it’s much more a story about the human spirit amid dire circumstances.

We don't get the backstory of the alien creatures, but the genuinely moving human connection is what makes 'Day One' much more than just another boilerplate disaster flick. Fantastic performances by Nyong'o, Quinn and the cat!
Although suspenseful, intense and well-produced, it's also repetitive and unimaginative.
It features a pair of sympathetic characters ... in a string of smartly staged and cleverly designed suspense sequences.

This entry is occasionally exciting, filled with fantastic effects, and chocked full of effective scares. The issues start with its less interesting characters. This script just doesn’t have the creativity of the first two.

Like a Hieronymous Bosch painting if he did motion art that hung in restaurants. Or the world's most high-concept, ill-conceived Samuel Beckett play. Michael Sarnoski swings & whiffs with a prequel offering a poor interpretation of the series' strengths.
Not only is it a rinse and repeat of the previous 2 films except in New York City but it literally provides none of the backstory the title promises.

The horror franchise goes retrograde to the first days of the apocalypse, with Lupita Nyong'o sent through the usual scareflick motions. A sequel content to just hit the rewind button to stuff we’ve already seen or envisioned.

A Quiet Place: Day One appropriately kept me in a frozen state, afraid to so much as crinkle a page in my notebook. It’s not a popcorn flick, though: Popcorn is too noisy. It’s more of a Raisinets movie.
This film is a far cry from the first installment that thrilled us in 2018. [Full review in Spanish]

Director Sarnoski and Krasinski use Sam’s story to elevate the excellent character driven emotion Lupito Nyong’o brings to the camera. Day One is exhausting and somewhat entertaining, so we’ll give this prequel a not too loud cheer.

Samira is a great movie character, easily the most complex character that has been a part of this franchise. She is not just reacting to the threat of the death angels. She is processing her own issues through every moment of the film.
Entertaining, but a disappointing letdown with too many missed opportunities to actually show what happened during day one.
A Quiet Place: Day One offers 99 minutes of nail-biting tension and thrills that keep you entertained and holding your breath. It has a sense of humor and strong characters.
“Day One” just about justifies its existence with a pair of savvy casting decisions: Lupita Nyong’o and a cat.
Like most of this series’s best action, the big bombastic noise is often a distraction from something far more intimate, and in Day One’s case, something far more existentially beautiful.
A Quiet Place: Day One, for better or worse, takes a somewhat different approach [than the previous entries], with varying degrees of success.

Despite a few bumps where the scene is too long or perhaps slower, the film manages to keep the viewer engaged and throw another twist at its audience. In effect, you can’t stop watching and rooting for the survivors on their journey to safety.

Day One does just what it sets out to, neither breaking the mold nor failing to meet the series’ expectations, but offering a sturdy and admirable spinoff with impressive performances and diverting thrills.

Persuades us that a few moments of unexpected joy, even humor, are not a necessary narrative respite from the relentless task of staying alive, but rather an expression of what it means to be human, and therefore all the more of a necessity.
“Day One,” like the two earlier films in the series, efficiently blends a human story with horror-movie tropes.  It doesn’t reinvent the wheel, but gives it another effective spin.
Sarnoski and his leads turn what could have easily been facile personal pursuits into the most important thing either character will ever do.
"Day One" is notable in the way it shrinks rather than expands the "Quiet Place" story.

Went in with high expectations and the film exceeds it. So much more than just a horror/disaster film. There is something incredibly human and emotional about this story. Stellar sound design & cinematography. Excellent performances by Nyong'o and Quinn.
Sarnoski, who also wrote the script, manages to turn the absurd journey of the protagonists into a surprisingly bittersweet story. [Full review in Spanish]
Nyong’o’s prodigious talents are sadly wasted in this noisy, pointless movie, which never approaches the cleverness — or the genuine scariness — of the first two in the franchise.
The movie follows a clear directive reasonably well. It is nothing but peril and exhaustion and superhuman resourcefulness in the face of two species not destined to get along.

What could have been an over-inflated expansion of a successful small-scale horror story is instead a worthy successor and a strong film in its own right. If every profitable movie must spawn a franchise, then this is exactly how it should be done.
How refreshingly nice it is to watch a summertime movie that lets us sit in our feelings and grim recollections this way, and figures that an adventure in its own right.
Not only is it technically well-made, it makes you feel things, which is why people still go to the movies, by and large.
A Quiet Place: Day One has way more to say about humanity than the trailer would have you think.
Sarnoski mostly scores with the endeavor, which retains most of the intensity of the brand name while gently opening the scope of the premise.
